title.narrative: COVID-19 UN Women: Kvinnors egenmakt i Cox's Bazar 2019-2021
COVID-19 UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021

description.narrative: By the end of the intervention, it is expected that: Women and girls, both Rohingya and host community, are empowered and resilient leaders, and are able to address and build social cohesion. The specific outcomes of this project will be: 1. Women have increased capacity and skills to participate and lead in community management and decision-making, in an enabling environment, and are linked with host community women, promoting social cohesion. 2. Capacities, skills and livelihood opportunities of women and adolescent girls are developed to enhance their self-reliance. 3. Capacity of all Camp-in-Charge (CiCs) is enhanced to enable gender-sensitive response to concerns (including protection needs) of women/girls and to able to provide better humanitarian services to all.

Omprogrammerade medel för att bekämpa covid-19 UN Women har ansökt om finansiering om 6,231 miljoner USD, ca 60 miljoner SEK för att utföra insatsen "Means to Lead: Empowering Rohingya refugee and Host Community Women through Leadership, Learning and Livelihoods" i Rohingya lägren i Bangladesh under perioden september 2019 - augusti 2022.
Insatsen syftar till att tillse att kvinnor och tonårsflickor i flyktinglägren i Cox´s Bazar har möjlighet att stärka sin egenmakt, sitt ledarskap och motståndskraft genom ökad kunskap och färdigheter. Detta ska göras genom att tillse 1) att kvinnor deltar i och leder beslutsfattande fora i lägren och att Rohingya kvinnor stärker länkarna med kvinnor i värdsamhället för att öka den sociala sammanhållningen; 2) att unga kvinnor och ungdomar får tillgång till utbildning, får möjlighet att utveckla färdigheter och får tillgång till egen inkomst; och 3) att Camp-In-Charges (CiC) stärker sin kapacitet för att bemöta kvinnors behov, för att utveckla skyddsåtgärder, och för att förbättra kvinnors tillgång till humanitära tjänster utan diskriminering. Den totala budgeten för verksamheten, egentligen en total budget för tre sammanslagna projekt, beräknas uppgå till 76 000 000 kronor, varav 38 450 000 kronor kommer att vidareförmedlas till implementeringspartners. Sida finansierar 79 % av den totala projektbudgeten.
Under år två och tre kommer insatsen skifta sitt fokus till det bredare Cox's Bazar-distriktet, i linje med pågående diskussioner kring en kommande lokal utvecklingsplan för distriktet, samt i ökad grad rikta in sig på värdsamhällen för att tydligare täcka behoven i ett av Bangladesh fattigare distrikt och samtidigt stärka förutsättningarna för distriktet att fortsatt vara värd för den stora flyktingbefolkningen.

Reprogrammed funds to address COVID-19 UN Women has applied for funding of SEK 60 00 000 to carry out the intervention "Means to Lead: Empowering Rohingya refugee and Host Community Women through Leadership, Learning and Livelihoods" in the Rohingya refugee camps and surrounding host comunities in Cox´s Bazar during the period September 2019 – August 2022.
The project aims to empower women, young women and adolescent girls in refugee camps and make them more resilient leaders by ensuring 1) women have increased capacity and skills to participate and lead in community management and decision-making, in an enabling environment, and are linked with host community women, promoting social cohesion; 2) capacities, skills and livelihood opportunities of women and adolescent girls are developed to enhance their self-reliance, and 3) capacity of all Camp-in-Charge (CiCs) are enhanced to enable gender-sensitive response to concerns (including protection needs) of women/girls and they are able to provide better humanitarian services to all. UN Women will implement the intervention through international non-governmental organizations with presence in the Rohingya refugee camps.
The intervention´s total budget is estimated to SEK 76 000 000, a total budget of three combined projects, and Sweden finances 79 % of the intervention. Approximately SEK 38 450 000 of the intervention budget will be forwarded from UN Women to implementing partners.
The intervention is relevant for the implementation of results area 5 in the Results strategy for Bangladesh 2014-2020, which aims to strengthen the capacity to prevent crises, conflicts and disasters, and increased resilience. Focus in this sub-result area is on vulnerable groups in refugee reception areas, among host communities and Rohingya refugees, especially women and children. The contribution also contributes towards sustainable development goals (SDGs) on gender equality (SDG 5) and on peace, justice and strong institutions (SDG 16).
During year 2 and 3, the intervention will shift its focus to target the wider Cox's Bazar district, in line with current discussions on a forthcoming district development plan, and increasingly target host communities to increasingly cover needs in one of Bangladesh's poorer districts, while increasing the districts ability to continue hosting the large refugee population.

sector.narrative: Facilitation of orderly, safe, regular and responsible migration and mobility

tag.narrative: 5.5 - Ensure women’s full and effective participation and equal opportunities for leadership at all levels of decision-making in political, economic and public life.
5.5 - Tillförsäkra kvinnor fullt och faktiskt deltagande och lika möjligheter till ledarskap på alla beslutsnivåer i det politiska, ekonomiska och offentliga livet.

title.narrative: UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021
UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021
UN Women: Women's Empowerment in Cox's Bazar 2019-2021

description.narrative: The COVID-19 outbreak led to restrictions that delayed several planned activities in the camps. The project workplan was revised to focus on activities that could contribute to COVID-19 responses and support preparatory work of the project. However, the activities could resume in the second part of the year, resulting in the following achievements: Output 1.1: Gender equality is integrated in the Rohingya camps’ government structures and processes.• Through the deployment of six Gender Field Officers (GFO) and 46 Rohingya volunteers (men 20 and women 26), the gender-sensitivity of 130 CiC staff across 13 camps was improved and regular monitoring at the camp level strengthened. • 12 dialogue sessions organized between the CiC and Rohingya women representatives, resulted in the development of an advocacy brief, with Rohingya women equipped with enhanced confidence to raise their concerns to the CiC. • Outreach sessions with the Rohingya community by GFOs and 46 Rohingya volunteers reached 64,759 people with COVID-19 awareness messages; 52,053 people were sensitized on the prevention of sexual exploitation and abuse (PSEA); and 10,525 community members with information on gender equalityand equity, gender diversity, GBV disclosure and gender and power. Output 1.2: Women have the capacity and skills to participate in community management and decision-making in an enabling environment with links to women’s networks, CBOs, and women development fora During the reporting period the project focused on documenting Rohingya and host community women’s situation, needs and solutions towards an enabling environment. • An advocacy brief “Rohingya Women Speak Up: Concerns, Demands and Solutions” was developed in consultation with Rohingya women leaders, CSOs and volunteers across 13 camps that is referenced in the GiHA WG “Urgent Call for Gender Actions in the COVID-19 Response in Cox’s Bazar” endorsed by United Nation’s Heads Of Sub Offices. • Gender Information Education and Communications material were developed by the project with inputs from the GiHA WG and Rohingya women leaders that promote gender equality, including messages targeting men and religious leaders and on the gendered impacts on COVID-19.• A Rapid Gender Assessment (RGA) was conducted in camps and host communities that highlights the gendered impact of the COVID-19 on women, 5girls, and other vulnerable populations. The RGA provided first responders with easy to access data on the gendered impact of COVID-19; and tailored interventions have referred to the RGA findings. • UN Women and IOM published the study "Honour in Transition: Changing Gender Norms among the Rohingya" that explores social norms barriers and opportunities to promote Rohingya women's leadership and empowerment in the camps in Cox's Bazar. The study serves as a reference for programme interventions aimed at women, girls and child welfare. • 1,334 Rohingya refugees and 1,246 host community members were sensitizedon issues related to women’s leadership and participation in decision-making processes at the community level and in the context of humanitarian activities Output 1.3: Opportunities, skills and livelihood opportunities of women and girls in host and Rohingya communities developed to enhance their leadership role and self-reliance • 29,436 Rohingya women and girls accessed information, services, awareness-raising and empowerment activities, including psychosocial support, referrals, first aid, and family planning support at five MPWCs (Multi-Purpose Women's Centers).• 3,358 Rohingya women and girls received training on tailoring and dressmaking, embroidery, sanitary napkin production, handicrafts, and homestead gardening, among others MPWCs.• 9,785 Rohingya women and girls and 8,884 men and boys were reached with information on gender, COVID-19 and social distancing, care work, menstrual hygiene, protection, domestic violence and MPWC services through volunteer outreach at household and community level. • 691 women (223 from Rohingya community and 468 from host community) are attending second chance education classes that began in December 2020 and51 teachers and volunteer teachers completed a Teachers Development Programme via online classes.
No indicator available - only a description of the activity results is published
